pa-prevalence.body:
The physical activity prevalence estimate was based on the prevalence of insufficient physical activity age-standardized to the WHO Standard Population 2016 and estimated in:

Reference: -Guthold R, Stevens GA, Riley LM, Bull FC. Worldwide trends in insufficient physical activity from 2001 to 2016: a pooled analysis of 358 population-based surveys with 1.9 million participants. Lancet Global Health 2018; http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S2214-109X(18)30357-7

In GoPA! we presented Physical Activity prevalence instead of insufficient physical activity. Therefore, the estimate was calculated as = 100 - prevalence of insufficient physical activity age-standardized.

In GoPA! we focus on prioritizing and ensuring comparability of data between GoPA! network countries. However, if the Country Contact decided and strongly suggested to include other data source for the physical activity prevalence estimate, the following requirements had to be:

a. Physical activity definition

Meeting the physical activity recommendation defined as: at least 150 minutes (2 hours and 30 minutes) a week of moderate-intensity, or 75 minutes (1 hour and 15 minutes) a week of vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity, or an equivalent combination of moderate- and vigorous-intensity aerobic activity.

b. Physical activity instruments

Based on self-reported physical activity assessed using the Global Physical Activity Questionnaire (GPAQ), the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) or a similar questionnaire covering activity at work/in the household, in transport, and during leisure time.

c. National or subnational representativeness

The prevalence of physical activity has been estimated with a national or subnational sample.

pa-inequalities.body:
Gender Inequalities in adults’ physical activity participation will be determined using the physical activity prevalence estimates by sex and presented as an equiplot.

Refrence: -Barros, AJD, Victora, CG. Measuring Coverage in MNCH: Determining and Interpreting Inequalities in Coverage of Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health Interventions. PLoS Med, (2013), https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001390

national-survey.body: In the Third set of Country Cards, the emphasis will be on the 'most recent' and 'next' national surveys that include physical activity questions. The standardized methodology developed for the First and Second set of Country Cards data collection will be used, as well as Country Contact's input to complete missing information and ensure the indicators have the most up to date information.

objective-measures.body:
Objective measurement of physical activity will be determined using the results of the systematic scoping review of accelerometer-measured physical activity datasets that include markers of cardiometabolic health : The Global Physical Activity Dataset (GPAD) catalogue led by Jonah J C Thomas and James P Sanders (School of Sport Exercise and Health Science, Loughborough University; National Centre for Sport and Exercise Medicine, Loughborough University; Centre for Lifestyle Medicine and Behaviour, Loughborough University).

The countries that have collected national physical activity data with objective measurement, the devices used to collect the data, and the physical activity prevalence estimates will be determined. For the missing data, Country Contacts will be consulted.

pa-research.body:
A systematic review was conducted to collect data for the research indicators. The development is described in:

- Ramírez Varela, A., Cruz, G.I.N., Hallal, P. et al. Global, regional, and national trends and patterns in physical activity research since 1950: a systematic review. Int J Behav Nutr Phys Act 18, 5 (2021). http://sci-hub.tw/10.1186/s12966-020-01071-x

The country’s contribution to worldwide physical activity and health research from 1950 to 2016 was estimated as the percentage of publications per country (total articles per country / total of articles worldwide) * 100.

research-quintiles.body:
A systematic review was conducted to collect data for the research indicators. The development is described in:

- Ramírez Varela, A., Cruz, G.I.N., Hallal, P. et al. Global, regional, and national trends and patterns in physical activity research since 1950: a systematic review. Int J Behav Nutr Phys Act 18, 5 (2021). http://sci-hub.tw/10.1186/s12966-020-01071-x

Research articles quintiles were calculated to display a comparison between countries on the Country Cards. The quintiles were labelled 1- high; 2-upper-middle; 3-middle; 4-lower-middle; and, 5-low.

gender-inequalities.body:
Gender inequalities in the authors of physical activity and health research will be determined using the results of the project: “ National capacity for physical activity and health research: a global analysis: inequality analysis”, led by Eduardo Ribes Kohn (Post-graduate Program in Epidemiology Federal University of Pelotas, Brazil) and Pedro C Hallal (Department of Kinesiology and Community Health, University of Illinois - Champaign/Urbana, USA.

Gender inequalities in the authors of physical activity and health research will be presented as an equiplot.

Reference: Barros, AJD, Victora, CG. Measuring Coverage in MNCH: Determining and Interpreting Inequalities in Coverage of Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health Interventions. PLoS Med, (2013), https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pmed.1001390

pa-promotion-research.body:
Based on Ramirez Varela, Andrea, et al. 'Global, regional, and national trends and patterns in physical activity research since 1950: a systematic review.' International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity 18.1 (2021): 1-15.

Green: Research is in the Q1 and Q2 quartiles of productivity

Yellow: Research is in the Q3 or Q4 quartiles of productivity

Red: Research is in the Q5 quartile of productivity or does not have physical activity research

Note: The final colors and country pyramid will be determined by the project manager after reviewing the data provided and using GoPA's standardized methods. Clarifications may be requested during this review process.

pa-promotion-policy.body:
Green: The country has a standalone plan/policy for physical activity and it is being implemented (at least half or more of the statements according to Klepac Pogrmilovic, Bojana, et al. 'National physical activity and sedentary behaviour policies in 76 countries: availability, comprehensiveness, implementation, and effectiveness.' International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity 17.1 (2020): 1-13.)

Yellow: The country has a standalone plan/policy for physical activity but it has a low implementation level (less than half of the statements according to Klepac Pogrmilovic, Bojana, et al. 'National physical activity and sedentary behaviour policies in 76 countries: availability, comprehensiveness, implementation, and effectiveness.' International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity 17.1 (2020): 1-13.)

Yellow: The country has an NCDs plan that includes physical activity and it is being implemented in any degree.

Red: The country does not have a physical activity plan/policy

Note: The policy triangles will account for the availability and implementation of physical activity policies.

• Availability in correspondence with the previous colors and categories (i.e., having standalone physical activity plan/policy, an NCDs plan that includes physical activity, or not having a physical activity plan/policy).

• Implementation will be defined by the indicator level of policy implementation. Green will represent intermediate to high implementation, yellow will represent low to intermediate implementation, and red will represent no implementation.

Note: The final colors and the country pyramid will be determined by the project manager after reviewing the data provided and using GoPA's standardized methods. Clarifications may be requested during this review process.

pa-promotion-surveillance.body:
Green: The country has periodic physical activity surveillance (data for first, most recent and next surveys)

Yellow: The country has physical activity surveillance but not with a clear periodicity (data for first OR most recent OR next surveys)

Red: The country does not have physical activity surveillance

Note: The final colors and the country pyramid will be determined by the project manager after reviewing the data provided and using GoPA's standardized methods. Clarifications may be requested during this review process.

national-pa-policy.body:
Physical activity policy is indicated by the totality of formal written policies, unwritten formal statements, written standards and guidelines, formal procedures, and informal policies (or lack thereof) that may directly or indirectly affect community- or population-level physical activity.

Defined by: - Klepac Pogrmilovic, B., O’Sullivan, G., Milton, K. et al. The development of the Comprehensive Analysis of Policy on Physical Activity (CAPPA) framework. Int J Behav Nutr Phys Act 16, 60 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1186/s12966-019-0822-5

The GoPA! Policy Directory (based on the Country Cards, Policy Inventory, and other public documents gathered by GoPA!) will be used to determine whether each of the 217 world countries has a physical activity policy/plan. The policy documents published in 2018 and beyond, as well as materials published prior to 2018 but covering the time period through 2018 (valid/enforced/current/applicable document), will be included in the 2024 Country Cards (third set).

How was this country classified?

According to the GoPA! Country Capacity for Physical Activity Promotion, the country will either be classified as having a standalone PA policy plan (i.e., exclusive for physical activity), an NCDs policy/plan integrating PA, or having no policy at all. Consequently, the country will be categorized as:

  1. Having a standalone PA policy/plan if at least one record of such a policy/plan appears in the documents retrieved for the country;
  2. Having an NCDs policy or plan that includes PA if all the documents retrieved were NCDs policies/plans that included PA and there was no standalone policy/plan record;
  3. Not having a PA policy if neither a standalone policy/plan nor an NCDs policy/plan including PA could be located.
